ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a new way of appreciating, talking about and writing history. The course was very engaging because the professor allowed the students in the seminar to interact with each other (even for the virtual Zoom seminars). By looking at multiple media of history-telling such as historical writing, painting, documentaries, audio recordings and primary sources, I learned to view history from multiple lenses. The questions asked in this course were important in shaping my deeper understanding history now.
how to approach writing about the past, approaching any historical reading with a critical eye, how to structure essays in a way that is engaging and informative

I learned that history, whether we realize it or not, is something we constantly interact with. I learned to view historyin monuments, memorials, books, essays, movies, shows, artwith a greater sense of respect and sensitivity, and most importantly, to think about what learning about the past could teach us today. In addition to becoming of better and keener observer of history, I learned how to write effectivelyto capture audience with tension in the beginning of a piece, to use my personal experiences and knowledge as a vehicle to go deeper into a theme, the importance of well-chosen evidence, and much more.

I think about history differently--before, I thought history was all about dry facts, etc., but this course really tried to emphasize personal engagement with history. I know think much more carefully about words/punctuation I use in my writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths are Professor Gordon's enthusiasm, care for the students and kindness. She makes discussions organic and guides us with many interactive exercises.

Professor Johnston Gordon is an enormous strength of this class. It would not be the same for me without her and she elevated it far beyond what the already strong course was. She is excellent at engaging each student on an individual level, no matter their level of experience with the subject.
variety of engaging and interesting materials (paintings, movies, podcasts, etc.)
I wish we learned more grammar/technical writing skills.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked the hybrid format.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is wonderful for learning how to appreciate history in a global sense. The class readings cover a broad range of historical topics. There is a lot of freedom given to the students to explore what they want outside of seminars. Professor Gordon is very supportive and helps you become a better informed reader and writer of the past.
Absolutely. Great writing course with an inspiring professor and an engaging learning environment. What's not to love?
Yes! This class gave me a completely new perspective on history writing beyond the five-paragraph paper. Professor Johnston Gordon is the best.

Yes. Learning from Professor Johnston has been amazing. Not only have I learned to interact with history in a completely new light, my writing improved greatly, and she really encouraged me to enjoy the writing process, and understand the value of thinking and grappling with my thoughts for long periods of time.
Yes! Professor Johnston was amazing, and I learned a lot.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: hybrid - one virtual seminar and one in-person seminar per week throughout the semester
We did a hybrid of in-person and virtual seminars.
Virtual seminar and in-person class (hybrid format)
On Mondays, we met in person, and on Wednesdays we met virtually.
